annotation.TEXT: A little bit after that, there'll be one additional fairy followed by over two dozen FOEs dropping in on the right, but the FOEs aren't a threat if you strike them immediately. (Or you could let a few of them fire to give you something to graze if you want.
Weirdly, sometimes it looks like a few bullets enter the field pointing horizontally at the top of the screen during a phase out, but then they go in the correct direction on the phase in.
Does this remind you of anything?
Awesome, but don't relax yet, there's still a few fairies and two columns of FOEs left!
Nice, although my homing shots did make that part easier. With a different team, that might've been another story.
For this spell, dodge the two aimed bullets, and then...

Now, I thought about ending the video here, but since today is my third anniversary of joining YouTube, let's continue and play out the rest of this game in this video! (Just the remainder of this run, though. Things like trying out the other teams and Extra stage will be done in later episodes.)
Bonus life at 70 million!

Oh, I never went over "Score" and "Max Score" yet. "Score" should be obvious enough, but you do get extra lives at certain values, which is the only way to get extra lives, but there are plenty of them to earn.
Now, we have one last conversation.
The second nonspell is the same as the first, except there's one more red ball that is aimed directly at you this time, so you'll have to move around a bit more.
When he starts his second spell, stay back and stand still at first. These small bullets are aimed, so just move left or right slightly at the last moment to dodge and graze them.

This will give you three options. The bottom (default) option resumes the game, the middle option restarts the game, and the top option returns you to the title screen. (The latter two will ask you to confirm them, and for those, the top choice is Yes, and the bottom choice is No.)
This is even easier than that nonspell, as you don't have to keep moving with the boss as he just sits still here! And once again, this works on all difficulties!
Oh, the fight's starting. Well, the rest of the "Point" value explanation will have to wait a bit.
Double layers of bullets on this nonspell, but the layers will move independently. Just try to find a safe path through.
Capture! After most spell cards, the boss will drop a bunch of power items, and because of the diminishing nature of the large power items, you'll probably want to grab those first if you can.
A large number of enemies appears at this point, but you can trivialize them with certain shot types, like this one.
I wouldn't try to go in between the satellites unless there's no other option. Also, be careful of some "moons" that might break their orbit as its "planet" goes offscreen and fly off independently.

Now for me at least, the game has a tendency to not always save accomplishments, so what I like to do is quickly start another game, then pause by holding Q for a second, then choose the top option and confirm it to return to the title screen.
And to top it all off, according to this game's music room, this guy's theme is "9999". Enough said.
If you're not careful, or the RNG just hates you, you could be trapped by those lasers easily.
Also, be mindful of the slow moving balls he releases as well. They should be easy enough to avoid though.
I don't know what's up with the completely blank dialog boxes there, but whatever.

Oh, and just like with IN, you get a choice after finishing stage 5. The top choice takes you to stage 6A, and the bottom one takes you to stage 6B. (But unlike IN, there's no need to finish 6A on a previous game to unlock 6B. I got this choice on my first playthrough.)
Okay, for the "last spell", he shoots out those phasing bullets at varying speeds, then aims a three-way laser at you during the phase out.

With this spell, the shots are initially roughly aimed at you, then split into pairs during a phase out. A good way to evade them is to move out of that cone of danger while they're phased out, then circle around back to the bottom after they phase in.
This one should be easy enough. Just bait the aimed shots towards a location where you can easily dodge them. Even circling around the boss might be a good idea.
Now here, a fairy will appear on the right, but go left and slaughter the FOEs first. Then after this, a fairy will appear on the left, with the FOEs on the right.
For his third spell, the rice shots always go in the same places, so just park between them. However, be ready to move when the occasional aimed V-spread comes your way.
Like Remilia.
In fact, you can trivialize a lot of the stage portions with a shot type like this. However, there are still a few tricky spots in later stages to watch out for.
Finally got it. That one can take a while, especially with certain shot types.
Also, dying drops your power to 0.00, but will also cause three large and four small power items to appear (which should get you between 2.80 and 2.90 power back).
After each stage, you'll get a stage clear bonus, which is affected by the stage number, difficulty, and number of lives you currently have left.
Move slightly to dodge the center laser, then while you're grazing it, start looking for openings in the phasing bullets. Be careful not to let the varying bullet speeds screw you up.
And of course, you have your usual four difficulties to choose from. Now, Easy is ridiculously easy, and the bosses won't use their Last Spells on Easy, so I'm going with Normal here.

And, in the bottom right corner, we have the difficulty, and another number. Now, that number is not the frame rate. Instead, it shows how many sprites are currently on the field. This includes you, your shots, the enemies, and their shots.
The second nonspell is the same as the first, so you know what to do!
If you should happen to run out of lives, it's game over (duh), and you'll get three options, all of which will need confirming.
Also, don't take too long on this spell. Those large yellow balls are still moving very slowly, and they could crowd you down below if given enough time.

Now, as for "Max Score"... Well, that's obviously your highest score, but only with the current team you're using. However, it doesn't separate high scores by difficulty, and that 1.3 billion that's showing up there was actually achieved on Hard.
I'll try to give some enemies a chance to at least get off a shot at me, just to be more fair (and possibly for grazing purposes).
Fourth nonspell is more of the same, except the bullet pairs are slightly more spread out. Now this one does feel a little harder.

Now, the "Point" value is interesting, and a bit complicated. I'll go over that in more detail later, but right now I'll just say you want to get the left number as high as you can, and keep the right number as low as you can.
He fires more of those scattering shots like from the last spell (although less dense), along with these aimed rotating lasers, which are the biggest threat.
Well, I think that covers just about everything I can think of involving the "Point" value. Yeah, that was unusually complicated.

So, if you do end up bombing here, you might want to try to get over to the extreme sides near the middle or top of the screen quickly, at least for a few seconds. This might be very tricky to do, though.

The right number is kind of like a quota/penalty value. If you bomb, the left number decreases by the value of the right number (down to a minimum of 1), and then the right number doubles (up to a maximum of 9999).
Hello, this is SomeGuy712x, and welcome to another Touhou flash game! This time, it's a big one: Project Nize Festival!

A warning when bombing in this game: You do not actually get any invincibility period from the bomb. It's possible to get hit by a shot right after you've bombed/deathbombed, while your previous circle is still on the screen. If you don't (or can't) deathbomb again then, you will still die.
Finally, a spell that's a challenge, maybe. Stay in the center, obviously, and try to slip through the aimed shots.
Assuming you're still in one piece, now you can relax... until the boss conversation ends, that is! Oh, and apparently I got a useless 1-up at 430 million!
This strategy is really useful on Lunatic.
Ah, we've reached the second boss, a dude in an eggplant costume. Oookay...

So, if you're playing for score, taking a death instead of deathbombing might be a better idea if the right number has already risen very high from previous bombs, so you can preserve most of what's remaining of the left number.
< Quit to title.
Extra life at 310 million, putting me at 9 reserve lives!
You should be able to find a wide enough gap to squeeze through though.
That was kind of close there. Now, the second nonspell is just like the first, except there are more total bullets.

Oh, yeah. This is important. Right when the battle with this particular boss starts, get off the bottom of the screen and position yourself in front of him. The reason why will quickly become apparent.
Well, at least this guy is dressed more normally than the previous boss.

Capture! Of course, to even face a "last spell", you have to meet a few requirements: Be on Normal or harder difficulty, don't die during the stage at all, have at least 1.00 power, and meet the "Point" quota (which is guaranteed if you never bombed).

Also, be warned that there's a major glitch with this spell: If you bomb here, the big lasers might start coming out of the green shots randomly, and probably hit you without warning. (This is more likely on the higher difficulties.)
For this spell, stay in the middle, obviously, and just tap dodge the aimed dark bullets. This isn't hard, but it takes a little while.
Alright, time for the final regular spell in stage 6A! (Yeah, this guy only gets three lifebars.)
The FOEs don't appear all at once, so this sequence will take a moment. Then there'll be another fairy, and over two dozen FOEs on the left. Same deal there.
Wow, this is silly. So, what's the next pattern gonna be?
Watch out for the fast aimed shots on this spell. They could catch you off guard.
Wow, that was close. Yeah, the bigger bullets' actual hitboxes aren't quite as big as their graphics, but that still felt like a tight squeeze.
And, as the big balls are aimed away from you, you won't have to move much, if at all.
Now, for this "last spell", just stay on the bottom and dodge in between stuff that comes your way.
Unlike most Touhou games, though, you don't have to worry about collecting the point items high up for max value. Their value is not affected at all by where you collect them.

Now, you want to finish this spell as fast as you can. See those slow moving circles of tiny black shots? Yeah, they get more dense as time goes on, and you'll have to deal with them along with the other stuff.
Oh, yeah, and there's this weirdo as well. I guess he's involved in this conversation too, much like Eirin and Reisen in IN's stage 5. We'll see more of that guy later.
And now I'm at full power, so unless I die or bomb, further power ups are near useless (being worth just 10 points each), but I'll still grab them anyway.
This is a good time to demonstrate that the bosses themselves have no collision hitbox for you to run into. You can safely pass through them, just like in Touhou 4.
Like Marisa.

Also, everybody gets the same type of bomb, a circle of doom that shoots out in front of you, sort of like in MoF, except the circle gradually shrinks down to nothing here. On a deathbomb, the circle sticks around for a longer amount of time.
Also, this spell has a safe spot the size of Nevada in the upper-right region, so unless you're using a shot type that can only fire forward, this is a cakewalk.
Alright, let's start the fight! The nonspells start off easy to graze, but be careful when the bullets change where they're going.
Alright! At this point, the game is won, but can I capture his "last spell" as well?
Looks like a lot of shots, but some will suddenly change direction away from you, so just sit on the bottom and concentrate on dodging the ones that do still come your way.
Now, I do intend to eventually show off every team in future episodes, but for this episode, I'm going to go with team Clairvoyance.
That seems to make sure the game saves everything I just did for me.
Watch out. The fairies come in threes here.
Now, just like most Touhou games, bosses will attack you with regular patterns (nonspells), and special patterns (spell cards).
Oh, look at that. I just got my second 1-up at 30 million points!

Now we come to stage 4 natural. "Natural"? Yep. Just like in IN, there are two different stage 4s (the other one being "Artificial"), and the one you play in a standard game depends on the team you've chosen.
For the fifth spell, move right up in front of the boss during the phase out, then slowly back away during the phase in.
Depending on where the bullets go, try not to let yourself get trapped.
However, dying does prevent you from facing the "last spell" in the current stage. (But if dying was necessary to preserve your "Point" value, you likely weren't going to meet the quota anyway.)
Alright, let's battle the eggplant dude! This nonspell isn't anything much to worry about. Just stay away from the big balls, and avoid the small shots that spawn from them.
This one can be tricky, so just try to dodge as best as you can.
What does "DAHAROOCA" mean? Anyway, dodge your way through the black triangles, then step out of the way of the aimed large balls.
The rest of stage 4's mooks aren't as tough. The FOEs come in sets of 5, and a few fairies occasionally appear, but that's not as bad as that earlier barrage could've been.
Like Sakuya.
This game pretty much plays like your standard Touhou game, borrowing many elements from Imperishable Night and Mountain of Faith.
Alright, I didn't get unlucky there.
Ooh, a spell card name that's in English! And it's just that, a simple gimmick. He aims large shots at you that have multiple smaller orbiting bullets.
And now we're in stage 2. You've probably noticed by now that the stage musics are based on IN's tunes.
Plays like Yukari.
Oh, and there's no limit to the number of continues, as far as I can tell.
For the second spell, we get some more phasing bullets, and he launches aimed lasers too. You can try to graze the lasers, but be careful of the direction they could swing as he moves.

If you can capture it, then that's more points for you. If you get hit, the spell ends immediately, and the game acts as if you bombed (you lose 1.00 power, and "Point" is affected accordingly). However, you won't die.
Depending on where they go, it could be tricky, or quite easy.

If you go with the bottom option, your score will reset and its ones digit will become the number of times you've continued (max. 9), "Point" will reset to 100/100, and three "F" items will appear, which instantly give you full power if you collect one.
Interestingly, the Youmu/Yuyuko imitators are placed before the Sakuya/Remilia imitators, so just keep that in mind when choosing your team.
You'll be greeted by a huge group of FOEs. Be careful.
Second nonspell is just like the first, though I think it's slightly faster.
For example, if you bomb at 250/100, it'll become 150/200. Bombing again from there would make it 1/400. Obviously, you want to avoid bombing too much.
What...? Yeah, his bullets phase out and in, just like with Reisen. This guy's totally ripping off Reisen!

More gameplay explanation (in case this is needed): To pause this game, you don't use Escape, like you would in normal Touhou games. Instead you use Q, and you have to hold Q down for about a second to pause.
Umm... I don't know what to say about this guy. Just be thankful he's wearing something in the spot that matters!
Yikes! That was close! But I'm almost there!
So, it may be possible to completely recover from bomb usage if you don't bomb too much and you collect enough power items.
Same old, same old, except the shots fired while the green bullets are frozen are aimed at you this time, so just move slightly to dodge them.
Ha, those FOEs didn't see that coming! (Or maybe they did, but just didn't care.)
Now, some of these shots are aimed at you, and some go their own way.
Like Youmu.

More about bombing: If you get hit, you can still "deathbomb" to save your life, like in most Touhou games, and you're given a generous amount of time to react (about half a second, or a full second with Clairvoyance).
Homing is especially useful, as it lets you keep attacking while you're making use of the autocollect line.
I'm going to go with 6A on this playthrough, and I'll show off 6B in a later episode.
Yeah! I just completed a perfect game (no bombs, no deaths, all spells captured)! Sweet! I thought for sure I'd make a mistake somewhere!
Just don't move around like a madman and this spell is easy.
And we're done. But wait, there's more? Yes, if you're on Normal or harder, you can face a "last spell", just like in IN.
And that's done. Now onto stage 3.
And I just got another life at 210 million!
And here we go! Now, just like any Touhou game, use the arrow keys to move, Z to shoot, X to bomb, and Shift to focus. And, just like in IN, focusing switches the team members and your shot type.
Then, it's just a matter of dodging some laser walls and aimed shots, which should be easy enough, unless the RNG hates you and throws an extended laser wall at you at the wrong time.

However, you must have at least 1.00 power to deathbomb, and deathbombing reduces your power by 2.00 (or all the way down to 0.00 if you have less than that). Also, deathbombing has the same effect on "Point" as normal bombing does.
Alright, for his first spell, get out of the way of the fast aimed spreads, and weave in between the bullets of the slower spreads. This shouldn't be too hard.
The first spell here can be quite tricky. Stay back and just try to find a path through the small bullets.
Oh, and that may look like a blind spot above the boss, but it's not. The aimed dark bullets will aim at you there too, so stay down here.

"Power" is your shot power, and it works just like in MoF. Small power items add 0.05 to it, and large power items add up to 1.00 to it, up to a maximum of 5.00, and you need at least 1.00 power to bomb.
Okay, now this "last spell" can be very annoying. "Welcome!" it says... Ha.
The Extra stage high scores are kept separate from the normal game, however. (I'll cover the Extra stage in a later episode.)
The FOE pairs appear with a single fairy, but depending on your attack, you might not even see the FOEs.
Second nonspell is just like the first. (Man, what's with all these repeated nonspells?)
Now, near the beginning of either stage 4, just after the first fairy appears, there are going to be a huge number of FOEs coming in from both sides of the top of the screen.
Plays like Reimu.
It doesn't really seem that much harder, so it's almost like you're getting double the graze for free!

Oh, and this is a survival spell. You're not meant to knock out this lifebar through damage (though you can see it draining very slowly). For this kind of spell, just avoid getting hit until time runs out to capture it.
Yeah, it's that guy again. If you went with 6B, though, your opponent would be somebody completely different.
One more thing to note: If you die, the left number of "Point" goes down by 10%, and the right number resets to 100 (for example, a death at 1000/1600 would change it to 900/100).
The stage portion is exactly the same between the two stage 4s (except for the background, which doesn't affect gameplay). The only real difference is the boss you'll face.
After that spell ends, move back to the bottom for the next spell.

Extra life at 130 million! Now, if you're daring, you can try to get real close to the boss on these nonspells to get some graze, but be careful. It would be really embarrassing if you got hit on these!
Whoa, that's a lot of enemies! Be careful there! That's probably the trickiest part of stage 1.
For this spell, at least on this difficulty, stay on the sides to dodge the big lasers (on Hard or Lunatic, moving between the lasers might be better).
Now, for this spell, do the exact same thing-- Sit right in front of the boss! And try to be close enough so that you get some nice graze as well.

Now, I say "up to 1.00" for large power items, because they actually diminish in value as your current power level increases. If you're between 0.05 and 0.50, they only give you 0.95 power. If you're between 0.55 and 1.00, they're worth 0.90, and so on.
Spell card start! If you can reduce the boss's current life bar to zero before time runs out, and without dying or bombing, you'll "capture" the spell and get bonus points.
Just ten more seconds...
Third nonspell is more of the same, except he launches close together pairs of bullets here.
Except, they aren't aimed perfectly for some reason. It's possible to put yourself in a spot where you don't have to move!
Be careful of the shot spreads that the fairies release in this stage.
< Resume game.
I'd probably be explaining more gameplay mechanics here while waiting for the battle to start, but I think I've mentioned everything that's relevant at this time.
This one makes me think of Reisen's "last spell", except vertical instead of horizontal. Just look for openings during the 3-second phase outs.
The top (default) option returns you to the title screen, the middle option will restart the game from the beginning, and the bottom option will resume the game from right where you are.
I even let those guys get off some shots and it was still easy. Now, the rest of the stage has some fairy pairs, and a couple of FOE pairs, which should be no problem.

But power items do have another use. If you've bombed and the right number of "Point" is above 100, grabbing power items reduces it until it drops back to 100, and if you're at full power, they reduce that number five times as fast!
For every 1.00 power you get, your shot powers up. Now my Reimu-style homing shots have appeared.
More FOEs, but not as dense here.
Next, we have our character selection screen, and just like in IN, you actually choose a team to play as, and their shot types are just like IN's shot types.
What's more, the lasers can glitch out as they're leaving the screen, and make all sorts of wacky moves to screw you over. (Far more likely on harder difficulties.)
Well, this has been a long episode, with 208 annotations that took me over 9 hours to put in! Yikes! Next time, a far less time-consuming episode! To be continued...
Kind of reminds me of Mokou's "Honest Man's Death", except without the sweeping laser.
Also, you can totally ignore the large balls while slipping through the small shots here, as they're aimed away from you.
Now, let's go over all those stats on the right. "Life" is your remaining reserve lives (you actually start with 4 lives total and not 3 in this game).

The circle shots coming from the left are aimed right at you, while the triangles from the right are aimed sort of relative to your position, possibly in an attempt to cut off your escape routes. Dodge carefully!
And it begins! His opener is similar to the previous guy's opener, except it's slower, so it should be a piece of cake.
Phased out bullets won't harm you, and they'll remain phased out for three seconds at a time. Look for an opening that you can use for when they phase back in.

Yes, that's right! This is so an imitation of a certain ice fairy's attack, except this nonspell is like this on all difficulties, even Lunatic! (There are just more bullets that won't ever hit you if you stay right in front of the boss on the higher difficulties.)
Now, it may look like there's a big blind spot circling the boss that you can use up there, but don't. The shots speed up if you approach, and in such a way that they will probably smack you.

And that's it! The game just drops you back at the title screen. Also, Extra was locked when I first played, but just clearing the stage 6A path on Easy was enough to unlock it for the team I was using. I'll cover Extra in a later episode.
Alright. Oh, and if you're at full power, it won't matter what order you pick up the power items in, so just quickly move up and autocollect them.
Interestingly, this spell is also used by the other stage 4 boss as well.
Regardless of which choice you make, the body of stage 6 will be the same, just like with the two stage 4s.
And already, we're at the stage 3 boss. Yeah, these stages are on the short side, and have no midbosses.

Now, back to the "Point" value: The game starts with it at 100/100, and every point item increases the left number by 10. Also, bullets cancelled as you approach a boss or from clearing a boss's pattern turn into tiny point items that add 1 each to it. (It caps at 9999.)
Then some slightly faster FOEs will appear on the right, then a fairy, then FOEs on the left, then another fairy. Shouldn't be too hard.
Now, right at the beginning of stage 5, you'll be greeted by half a dozen fairies. Don't panic. Dodge their aimed shots, take them down, and gain some decent power if you need it.
And let the fight begin! Right away you'll notice his opener is similar to Reisen's opener, but that's just a coincidence, right?

Okay, now this spell is legitimately challenging. You've got amulets randomly flying around, along with some frequent aimed groups of amulets. Keep moving to throw off the aimed ones and dodge the random ones.
< Give up and retry.
You may want to consider using a bomb here, especially on Hard and Lunatic, but let's see if I can get through this part without needing one.

Now, as for his "last spell", he'll release bullet spreads from himself, but aimed bullet spreads will also spawn just above you. Pay more attention to those, and just keep tapping left or right to dodge through them.
LOL at the pointless 1-up at 570 million!
And we've made it to the boss already. I have no idea what they're saying, but I'll leave each page of text up for a few seconds in case anyone can read it.
Okay, very important: As soon as this spell ("AA Outbreak") starts, move towards the middle, and stay within the rotating square. You will not capture this otherwise.
Like Alice.
Alright, we've reached the boss, and it's a member of one of the other teams, just like how IN does it.
After that, you'll have a few seconds to catch your breath (if you need to) before the final mook gauntlet.
Oh, are we there already? That seemed fast... Whoa!

In fact, you could potentially hit the cap of 9 reserve lives, then die, and still find that you can earn more. The first 1-up was at 10 million points, and I'll point out more of those 1-up marks as I hit them.
For this spell, move up immediately, as the bullets spawn from the bottom of the screen.
Also, be careful of the big yellow shots, as they might obscure a smaller shot that could suddenly surprise you.
Oh, it may not seem bad now, but try timing out this spell on Lunatic (or even Hard or Normal), and you'll see what I mean!
Fairies are slightly tougher mooks and take more of a beating to defeat. They always drop power items, occasionally being large power items.
Like Yuyuko.
That left number determines how much point items and grazes are worth. (There is no graze counter, but grazing is still worth points, and can be worth a lot.)

Here we go! First, veer left and take out the first fairy, then try to deal with all of the FOEs entering from both sides of the screen, along with additional fairies as best you can. Homing and spread shot types rule here!
20 seconds left...
You probably want to stay focused on this one, so you don't move too fast.

Even in your flash game, FOE! There were our first mooks, and they drop your usual power and point items, and like most Touhou games, you can autocollect the items by moving to the upper part of the field.
Try to tap dodge the aimed ones as much as you can, but make bigger movements when necessary, to dodge the other bullets or to turn around.
